english: full (from eating); satiated; replete; to satisfy

etymology.interpretation: 食 marks the domain of food and eating, while 包 supplies the sound bǎo and evokes wrapping/containing. Their combination points to being filled or packed with food, yielding meanings like “full” and “satiated.”
etymology.simplification: Simplified by replacing the semantic component 食 with the abbreviated radical 饣, a standard radical simplification that leaves the phonetic 包 unchanged.

examples.chinese: 这一餐吃得很饱(這一餐吃得很飽)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè yī cān chī de hěn bǎo.
examples.english: I ate my fill this meal.

examples.chinese: 让孩子吃饱穿暖(讓孩子吃飽穿暖)。
examples.pinyin: Ràng háizi chī bǎo chuān nuǎn.
examples.english: Make sure the children have enough to eat and warm clothes.
